content.description: Independent, super fun, and just hard enough. From the two-hand undercling, make big moves straight up and top out on knobs.
content.location: Look for Cross-Eyed Nurse, the double arÃªte problem visible from Bill Boulder. The Peanut is a couple tiers up the hill from it.

content.description:
Start on a big jug down and right, then move left to the hollow-sounding, flat rail. feet get really good at this point. Move up and left off a nice Side-pull, then tiny crimp to a perfect little jug. The oft-used and apt phrase "gently overhanging" comes to mind.  

  the big flaky jug at the top sketched me out, but I'm heavy and suspect that everything is just waiting to break.
content.protection: a good spotter and a pad under the top out should suffice.

content.description: First top roped by Bob Murray and friends, eventually flashed ground up with no rope in the spring of 2009. Crux near the top, Grab a left hand sloper and make a large move up and right to better holds. Mantle on a jug high off the deck! Head trip for sure!
content.protection: As many pads as possible unless you are toproping it.
content.location: Huge vertical face up and left about 15 feet from The Peanut

content.description: The alluring left-leaning arete above the Bill Boulder. Start right hand on the lowest part of the arete and left on a bad sloper under the roof. Move up and left to an undercling pinch and cruise slopers and heelhooks to a mellow topout.
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter. The landing drops off severely to the right, try hard to keep from falling into the pit.
content.location: Just past the Bill Boulder to the left, this steep arete is clearly visible just uphill in the stack of boulders.

content.description: The dense cluster of boulders and caves uphill from the Bill Boulder houses several great problems including The Peanut, Cross-Eyed Nurse, the Murray Arete, and uncountable other lines lurking in the corners and chasms, waiting to be discovered. Basically every problem in this area requires multiple pads and spotters and a willingness to commit.
